title: 27 Month Questionnaire
/COMMUNICATION/questions/0/question: Without your giving him clues by pointing or using gestures, can your child carry out at least three of these kinds of directions? a. “Put the toy on the table.” d. “Find your coat.” b. “Close the door.” e. “Take my hand.” c. “Bring me a towel.” f. “Get your book.”
/COMMUNICATION/questions/1/question: If you point to a picture of a ball (kitty, cup, hat, etc.) and ask your child, “What is this?” does your child correctly name at least one picture?
/COMMUNICATION/questions/2/question: When you ask her to point to her nose, eyes, hair, feet, ears, and so forth, does your child correctly point to at least seven body parts? (She can point to parts of herself, you, or a doll. Mark “sometimes” if she correctly points to at least three different body parts.)
/COMMUNICATION/questions/3/question: Does your child correctly use at least two words like “me,” “I,” “mine,” and “you”?
/COMMUNICATION/questions/4/question: Does your child make sentences that are three or four words long? Please give an example:
/COMMUNICATION/questions/5/question: Without giving your child help by pointing or using gestures, ask him to “put the book on the table” and “put the shoe under the chair.” Does your child carry out both of these directions correctly?
/GROSS MOTOR/questions/0/question: Does your child walk either up or down at least two steps by himself? He may hold onto the railing or wall. (You can look for this at a store, on a playground, or at home.)
/GROSS MOTOR/questions/1/question: Does your child run fairly well, stopping herself without bumping into things or falling?
/GROSS MOTOR/questions/2/question: Does your child jump with both feet leaving the floor at the same time?
/GROSS MOTOR/questions/3/question: Without holding onto anything for support, does your child kick a ball by swinging his leg forward?
/GROSS MOTOR/questions/4/question: Does your child jump forward at least 3 inches with both feet leaving the ground at the same time?
/GROSS MOTOR/questions/5/question: Does your child walk up stairs, using only one foot on each stair? (The left foot is on one step, and the right foot is on the next.) She may hold onto the railing or wall.
/FINE MOTOR/questions/0/question: Does your child use a turning motion with her hand while trying to turn doorknobs, wind up toys, twist tops, or screw lids on and off jars?
/FINE MOTOR/questions/1/question: Does your child flip switches off and on?
/FINE MOTOR/questions/2/question: After your child watches you draw a line from the top of the paper to the bottom with a pencil, crayon, or pen, ask him to make a line like yours. Do not let your child trace your line. Does your child copy you by drawing a single line in a vertical direction?
/FINE MOTOR/questions/3/question: Does your child stack seven small blocks or toys on top of each other by herself? (You could also use spools of thread, small boxes, or toys that are about 1 inch in size.)
/FINE MOTOR/questions/4/question: Can your child string small items such as beads, macaroni, or pasta “wagon wheels” onto a string or shoelace?
/FINE MOTOR/questions/5/question: After your child watches you draw a line from one side of the paper to the other side, ask her to make a line like yours. Do not let your child trace your line. Does your child copy you by drawing a single line in a horizontal direction?
/PROBLEM SOLVING/questions/0/question: Does your child pretend objects are something else? For example, does your child hold a cup to his ear, pretending it is a telephone? Does he put a box on her head, pretending it is a hat? Does he use a block or small toy to stir food?
/PROBLEM SOLVING/questions/1/question: Does your child put things away where they belong? For example, does she know her toys belong on the toy shelf, her blanket goes on her bed, and dishes go in the kitchen?
/PROBLEM SOLVING/questions/2/question: When looking in the mirror, ask “Where is _______?” (Use your child’s name.) Does your child point to his image in the mirror?
/PROBLEM SOLVING/questions/3/question: If your child wants something she cannot reach, does she find a chair or box to stand on to reach it (for example, to get a toy on a counter or to “help” you in the kitchen)?
/PROBLEM SOLVING/questions/4/question: While your child watches, line up four objects like blocks or cars in a row. Does your child copy or imitate you and line up four objects in a row? (You can also use spools of thread, small boxes, or other toys.)
/PROBLEM SOLVING/questions/5/question: When you point to the figure and ask your child, “What is this?” does your child say a word that means a person or something similar? (Mark “yes” for responses like “snowman,” “boy,” “man,” “girl,” “Daddy,” “spaceman,” and “monkey.”) Please write your child’s response here:
/PERSONAL-SOCIAL/questions/0/question: If you do any of the following gestures, does your child copy at least one of them? a. Open and close your mouth. c. Pull on your earlobe. b. Blink your eyes. d. Pat your cheek.
/PERSONAL-SOCIAL/questions/1/question: Does your child eat with a fork?
/PERSONAL-SOCIAL/questions/2/question: When playing with either a stuffed animal or a doll, does your child pretend to rock it, feed it, change its diapers, put it to bed, and so forth?
/PERSONAL-SOCIAL/questions/3/question: Does your child push a little wagon, stroller, or other toy on wheels, steering it around objects and backing out of corners if he cannot turn?
/PERSONAL-SOCIAL/questions/4/question: Does your child call herself “I” or “me” more often than her own name? For example, “I do it” more often than “Juanita do it.”
/PERSONAL-SOCIAL/questions/5/question: Does your child put on a coat, jacket, or shirt by himself?
